title: Kym Marsh says her Coronation Street character will be "gone for a very long time"
text:
Kym Marsh says her Coronation Street character will be "gone for a very long time" Kym says people won't recognise Michelle after the devastating loss of her baby boy on Corrie Share Get soaps updates directly to your inbox + Subscribe Thank you for subscribing! Actress Kym Marsh says her Coronation Street character will be “gone for a very long time” following the devastating loss of her baby boy. 
Kym , who has received high praise for her portrayal of heartbroken mum Michelle, says people won’t recognise the Corrie wedding planner and barmaid as she struggles to cope following the death of her son Ruairi at 23 weeks of pregnancy. 
Kym went through a similar ordeal eight years ago when her son Archie was born at 21 weeks. 
She told the Manchester Evening News : “I think in the coming weeks you’re going to see a different Michelle, because she is quite broken at the moment, and so you’re probably not going to see much of the old Michelle. Kym was praised for her portrayal of heartbroken mum Michelle (Photo: ITV) Read More Click to play Tap to play The video will start in 8 Cancel Play now Kym Marsh tears up as caller reveals she suffered stillbirth Share this video Watch Next 
“You’re going to see someone that many people don’t recognise and that is actually something that I had. 
“Nobody recognised me when I had gone through all of that.” 
This week viewers saw Michelle becoming inconsolable when, to add to her grief, she is informed that her son’s birth can’t be registered. 
By law, parents can’t receive a birth certificate if a child is born dead before 24 weeks of pregnancy. The actress said her character won't be the same for a long time (Photo: ITV) 
Kym added: “She is broken, she is completely broken and so for a good few weeks, you’re going to see quite a broken Michelle. You might start to see glimmers of her in the future storylines but not for a very long time. 
“Her flicky eyeliner might be gone for some time.” 
Kym, 40, agreed to take part in the harrowing storyline to honour her son while helping others going through a similar ordeal. 
Kym was told by producer Kate Oates that she didn’t have to go ahead with the storyline, for which the soap worked with the stillbirth charity Sands, if she didn’t want to. And she had a psychotherapist on set with her at all times. Kym had a therapist with her on set as she filmed the storyline (Photo: ITV) (Photo: ITV) 
She watched the heart-wrenching episodes with her eldest children David and Emilie, 21 and 19, and her mum Pauline, who opened up about her own tragic loss to her family. 
Kym explained: “My mum lost a baby between my older brother and sister and we all knew about that anyway but back then, they didn’t have scans and things like that. 
“Her baby tragically died in the womb and once they realised that my mum had to deliver her baby and she never even got to see her baby. 
“What was interesting was, although we’d heard my mum’s story, after we watched the episode, we were all sat in the room and she just started to talk and talk and talk and other things that we hadn’t heard before and her own feelings and I just went ‘there you go, that’s what this is about.’” Like us on Facebook
